Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: Collaborative Research: TrajAnalytics: A Cloud-Based Visual Analytics Software System to Advance Transportation Studies Using Emerging Urban Trajectory Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced technologies in sensing and computing have created urban trajectory datasets of humans and vehicles travelling over urban networks. Understanding and analyzing the large-scale, complex data reflecting city dynamics is of great importance to enhance both human lives and urban environments. Domain practitioners, researchers, and decision-makers need to manage, query and visualize such big and dynamics data to conduct both exploratory and analytical tasks. To support these tasks, this project develops a open source software tool, named TrajAnalytics, which integrates computational techniques of scalable trajectory database, intuitive and interactive visualization, and high-end computers, to explicitly facilitate interactive data analytics of the emerging trajectory data.

The software provides a new platform for researchers in transportation assessment and planning to directly study moving populations in urban spaces. Researchers in social, economic and behavior sciences can use the software to understand the complicated mechanisms of urban security, economic activities, behavior trends, and so on. Specifically, this software advances the research activities in the community of transportation studies. The software also acts as an outreach platform allowing government agencies to communicate more effectively with the public with the real-world dynamics of city traffic, vehicles, and networks. The integration of research and education prepares the next generation workforce, where students across multi-disciplines can benefit through their participation in the development and use of the software.

In order to lay the foundations for effective analysis of urban trajectory datasets, this software (1) facilitates easy access and unprecedented capability for researchers and analysts with a cloud-based storage and computing infrastructure; (2) develops a parallel graph based data model, named TrajGraph, where massive trajectories are managed on a large-scale graph created from urban networks which is naturally amenable for studying urban dynamics; and (3) provides a visualization interface, named TrajVis, which supports interactive visual analytics tasks with a set of visualization tools and interaction functions. A variety of transportation-related researchers from geography, civil engineering, computer science participate in the design, evaluation, and use of the software. This robust and easy-to-use software enables the users to conduct iterative, evolving information foraging and sense making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project creates a visual analytics software system, TrajAnalytics, which has been developed and released as an open-source software for domain experts and researchers to visually mine and analyze patterns from urban trajectory datasets. The mobility patterns and dynamics of urban cities and their citizen can be manifested by visually studying the moving paths of human, taxi, bus, fleets, cars, and so on. The software provides exploratory data visualization tools to reveal knowledge intuitively. It makes investigations easier of questions important to transportation, geography, urban planning and other related fields.

 

Intellectual Merit:

TrajAnalytics provides a new visual analytics system of urban mobility data. It is built up on infrastructures of a cloud platform or a local Web-server. TrajAnalytics is designed to seamlessly integrate data modeling and visualization functions. A Geo+Trajectory model is developed to incorporate different types of raw data and match them to geographic structures. The modules of data loading and map matching enable users to upload and transform their own data easily. A TrajBase database is developed to store both the trajectory data and the geographic data. Effective spatio-temporal indexing algorithms are designed of these data to support interactive visual queries. A TrajVis visual interface is designed which allows users to perform interactive queries and visualizations of multiple trajectory attributes in geo-contexts. It supports common tasks for urban studies and is extensible for adding more visual functions. The software is tested with domain researchers and users to evaluate its usability and effectiveness. The software fosters a community of researchers to conduct transportation-related studies in a more efficient and productive way. Moreover, the intellectual designs and algorithms of this system contribute to the fields of graph-based big data management, spatiotemporal visualization, and human machine interaction.

Broader Impacts:

The mobility and behavior of people and transportation vehicles in motion form a basic component in human society, which is closely related to urban study and economic activities. TrajAnalytics facilitates easy, online exploration of urban trajectory data by a variety of domain users. The software advances a broad spectrum of applications by enabling researchers to tackle the data challenge. Therefore, urban transportation issues and policies can be better understood and addressed. TrajAnalytics can help users from multiple sectors including academic institutions, urban planning and design, business, finance, public services, and local governments by leveraging the advanced computation and visualization capabilities to utilize the large, complex, and rapidly accumulating population mobility data.

The PIs have provided over 40 workshops/sessions and talks in conferences to train users and promote TrajAnalytics. So far, TrajAnalytics has had more than 3,000 downloads, and a user community of more than 500 domain users has been developed. More than 400 hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students have been trained on trajectory data visualization, spatial database, spatial programming, and spatial social network analysis based on materials generated from this project.
